quiz.title: Unit 4: Forces (Quiz 1)
quiz.subtitle: Introduction to Forces and Newton's First Law (20 Questions)
quiz.subject: Physics
quiz.topic: Force Definitions, Inertia, and Net Force

questions.question: What is a force?
options: The amount of matter in an object
A push or pull that can change an object's motion
The speed at which an object moves
questions.explanation: A force is defined as a push or pull that can cause an object to accelerate, change direction, or deform.

questions.question: Newton's First Law of Motion is also known as:
questions.explanation: Newton's First Law describes inertia - an object's tendency to resist changes in its motion.

questions.question: According to Newton's First Law, what happens to an object at rest when no net force acts on it?
questions.explanation: An object at rest stays at rest unless acted upon by a net external force.

questions.question: What is inertia?
options: The force of gravity on an object
An object's resistance to changes in motion
The amount of friction between surfaces
questions.explanation: Inertia is the property of matter that resists changes in velocity.

questions.question: Two people push a car in the same direction with forces of 300 N and 400 N. What is the net force?
questions.explanation: When forces act in the same direction, add them: 300 N + 400 N = 700 N.

questions.question: A book is pushed with 20 N east and pulled with 15 N west. What is the net force?
questions.explanation: Opposite directions: 20 N east - 15 N west = 5 N east.

questions.question: Newton's Second Law states that:
options: For every action there is an equal and opposite reaction
An object at rest stays at rest
Energy cannot be created or destroyed
questions.explanation: F = ma is the mathematical expression of Newton's Second Law.

questions.question: What is the SI unit of force?
questions.explanation: The newton (N) is the SI unit of force, defined as 1 kg·m/s².

questions.question: A 5 kg object accelerates at 3 m/s². What net force acts on it?
questions.explanation: F = ma = 5 kg × 3 m/s² = 15 N.

questions.question: Which object has the greatest inertia?
questions.explanation: Inertia depends on mass - the bowling ball has the most mass and thus the greatest inertia.

questions.question: A car moves at constant velocity. What can be said about the net force acting on it?
options: Net force equals the car's weight
Net force equals the engine force
questions.explanation: Constant velocity means no acceleration, so by F=ma, net force must be zero.

questions.question: A 10 N force and a 6 N force act in opposite directions on an object. What is the net force?
questions.explanation: 10 N - 6 N = 4 N in the direction of the larger force.

questions.question: What acceleration will a 4 kg object have if a 12 N net force acts on it?
questions.explanation: a = F/m = 12 N / 4 kg = 3 m/s².

questions.question: Which scenario demonstrates Newton's First Law?
options: A book sliding to a stop on a table
A ball falling faster as it drops
questions.explanation: The book demonstrates inertia - it continues moving until friction (external force) stops it.

questions.question: A force of 25 N gives an object an acceleration of 5 m/s². What is the object's mass?
questions.explanation: m = F/a = 25 N / 5 m/s² = 5 kg.

questions.question: What is the net force on an object with balanced forces?
questions.explanation: Balanced forces cancel each other out, resulting in zero net force.

questions.question: Which force always acts opposite to the direction of motion?
questions.explanation: Friction always opposes the direction of motion or attempted motion.

questions.question: A shopping cart is pushed with 30 N forward and experiences 10 N friction backward. What is the net force?
questions.explanation: 30 N forward - 10 N backward = 20 N forward.

questions.question: What happens to acceleration if mass increases but net force stays the same?
questions.explanation: From a = F/m, if mass increases and F is constant, acceleration decreases.

questions.question: A 2 kg object experiences a net force of 8 N. What is its acceleration?
questions.explanation: a = F/m = 8 N / 2 kg = 4 m/s².

scoreMessages.90: Excellent! You have a strong grasp of fundamental force concepts and Newton's First Law.
scoreMessages.70: Good job! You understand the core ideas but should review net force calculations.
scoreMessages.50: A fair effort. Focus on the definitions of force, inertia, and practicing F=ma problems.
